title: Biden’s Pick to Lead ATF Faces Opposition From Senate Republicans
sub_head: David Chipman, a longtime ATF agent turned gun control advocate, would lead agency
body:
President Biden’s pick to lead a key agency that will be involved in the administration’s efforts to curb gun violence faced opposition Wednesday from Republican senators, as some cited his advocacy for tighter gun control laws.
David Chipman, if confirmed, would lead the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.
In an evenly divided Senate, Mr. Chipman needs to secure all 50 Democratic votes to be confirmed, with Vice President Kamala Harris casting a tiebreaking vote.
Mr. Chipman spent 25 years as an ATF agent and oversaw the bureau’s firearms programs, among other roles. Mr. Chipman most recently served as a top policy adviser to the gun-control organization Giffords, led by former Democratic Arizona Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, who was shot in 2011 along with 18 others in a Tucson-area supermarket parking lot. Six people died in the attack.
At a hearing Wednesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Sen. Chuck Grassley, (R., Iowa), the committee’s minority leader, likened Mr. Chipman’s nomination to “putting a tobacco executive in charge of the Department of Health and Human Services.”
